factoid: Kozlóvski said 'The commander in chief is engaged.'
Kozlóvski went hurriedly up to the unknown general.
Kozlóvski blocked the unknown general's way to the door.
Kozlóvski asked 'Whom shall I announce?'.
The unknown general looked disdainfully down at Kozlóvski.
The unknown general was rather short.
The unknown general was surprised that anyone should not know him.
Kozlóvski repeated 'The commander in chief is engaged.'.
The unknown general's face clouded.
The unknown general's lips quivered.
The unknown general's lips trembled.
The unknown general took out a notebook.
The unknown general hurriedly scribbled something in pencil.
The unknown general tore out a leaf from the notebook.
The unknown general gave the leaf to Kozlóvski.
The unknown general stepped quickly to the window.
The unknown general threw himself into a chair.
The unknown general gazed at those in the room as if asking 'Why do they look at me?'.
The unknown general lifted his head.
The unknown general stretched his neck as if he intended to say something.
The unknown general began to hum to himself with affected indifference.
The unknown general produced a queer sound.
The unknown general's queer sound immediately broke off.
The door of the private room opened.
Kutúzov appeared in the doorway.
The unknown general had a bandaged head.
The unknown general bent forward as though running away from some danger.
The unknown general made long, quick strides with his thin legs.
The unknown general went up to Kutúzov.
The unknown general uttered 'Vous voyez le malheureux Mack' in a broken voice.
Kutúzov's face remained perfectly immobile for a few moments while he stood in the open doorway.
Wrinkles ran over Kutúzov's face like a wave.
Kutúzov's forehead became smooth again.
Kutúzov bowed his head respectfully.
Kutúzov closed his eyes.
Kutúzov silently let Mack enter his room before him.
Kutúzov closed the door behind him.
A report had been circulated that the Austrians had been beaten.
A report had been circulated that the whole army had surrendered at Ulm.
The report proved to be correct.
Within half an hour, adjutants had been sent in various directions.
The orders showed that the Russian troops had hitherto been inactive.
The orders showed that the Russian troops would soon have to meet the enemy.
Prince Andrew was a rare staff officer whose chief interest lay in the general progress of the war.
Prince Andrew saw Mack.
Prince Andrew heard the details of Mack's disaster.
Prince Andrew understood that half the campaign was lost.
Prince Andrew understood all the difficulties of the Russian army’s position.
Prince Andrew vividly imagined what awaited the Russian army and the part he would have to play.
Prince Andrew felt a joyful agitation at the thought of the humiliation of arrogant Austria.
Prince Andrew thought that in a week’s time he might see and take part in the first Russian encounter with the French since Suvórov met them.
Prince Andrew feared that Bonaparte’s genius might outweigh all the courage of the Russian troops.
Prince Andrew could not admit the idea of his hero being disgraced.
Prince Andrew was excited and irritated by these thoughts.
Prince Andrew went toward his room to write to his father.
Prince Andrew wrote to his father every day.
In the corridor, Prince Andrew met Nesvítski.
Prince Andrew shared a room with Nesvítski.
Prince Andrew met wagon Zherkóv in the corridor.
Prince Andrew and wagon Zherkóv were as usual laughing.
Nesvítski asked Prince Andrew why he was so glum.
Nesvítski noticed Prince Andrew's pale face.
Nesvítski noticed Prince Andrew's glittering eyes.
Bolkónski answered that there was nothing to be gay about.
Strauch was an Austrian general on Kutúzov’s staff in charge of the provisioning of the Russian army.
Strauch was a member of the Hofkriegsrath who had arrived the previous evening.
Strauch came toward Prince Andrew, Nesvítski, and wagon Zherkóv from the other end of the corridor.
The corridor was wide enough for the generals to pass the three officers quite easily.
Wagon Zherkóv pushed Nesvítski aside with his arm.
Wagon Zherkóv said in a breathless voice 'They're coming!... they're coming!... Stand aside, make way, please make way!'.
The generals were passing by looking as if they wished to avoid embarrassing attentions.
A stupid smile of glee appeared on the face of wagon Zherkóv.
Wagon Zherkóv seemed unable to suppress the smile.
Wagon Zherkóv said in German 'Your excellency' while stepping forward and addressing the Austrian general.
Wagon Zherkóv said 'I have the honor to congratulate you.'.
Wagon Zherkóv bowed his head.
Wagon Zherkóv scraped first with one foot and then with the other awkwardly.
The member of the Hofkriegsrath looked at wagon Zherkóv severely.
The member of the Hofkriegsrath saw the seriousness of wagon Zherkóv's stupid smile.
The member of the Hofkriegsrath gave wagon Zherkóv a moment’s attention.
The member of the Hofkriegsrath screwed up his eyes showing that he was listening.
The member of the Hofkriegsrath added 'I have the honor to congratulate you.'.
The member of the Hofkriegsrath said that General Mack had arrived, quite well, only a little bruised just here.
The member of the Hofkriegsrath pointed with a beaming smile to General Mack's head.
The member of the Hofkriegsrath frowned.
The member of the Hofkriegsrath turned away.
The member of the Hofkriegsrath went on.
